data.text: Self-Inflatable Pillow and Mat are Not Comfortable
I bought a self inflatable pillow and mat and did a first cycling trip away. Does anyone have any recommendations because sleeping was not great. Pillow too hard and mat not great.
Sea to Summmiy do great, lightweight kit.
data.author: Taniya Morris

data.text: yes, i love their pillow.
data.author: Heni Amundsen

data.text: Tried exped matt's? Light, pretty comfortable, easy to make less firm once on it
data.author: Michael Bulmer

data.text: I find that using my pannier with a bit of clothes inside makes a better pillow than a blow up pillow.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: Or clothes inside the sleeping bag stuff sack.
data.author: Steve Williams

data.text: Forclaz treking 700 lightweight mat from decathlon
data.author: Tony Lane

data.text: Do not inflate pillow fully 3/4 is fine. Overinflate the mat - blow in additional air. Put all sofl stuff you carry like clothes underneath the mat. Set your tent on a grassy area if possible
data.author: Vladimir Belyaev

data.text: All depends on how much air you put in them
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: Don't fully inflate them, takes a few times to get it perfect. Also I never sleep well first night in the tent but by the 3rd night I sleep like a log
data.author: James Carter

data.text: Thermarest mattress everytime. I fold clothes up inside a fleece as a pillow
data.author: Tina Brocklebank

data.text: DONT over inflate mat. Fill it, lie down, then release air. When living flat, no part of your body should touch the floor, but if you raise your head, you should feel your hips touch ground. As for the pillow, 3/4 full it should cradle your head.
data.author: Richard Ham

data.text: that's the way I do it too.
data.author: Karel Castelein

data.text: Take a quilted jacket use as pillow
data.author: Dave Prestidge

data.text:
https://youtu.be/aPxddfPf5UQ
The KEY to Great Sleep Outdoors
youtube.com
data.author: Elƒ´na Cƒìrpa

data.text: I havevtried many different until I found what worked for me. My recommendations may not be right for you. I bought a lot thru REI because of their return policy. I use Nemo Insulated vector pad. I have av55 degree sleeping bag I unzip and use as quilt. I carry two pillows- Sea to Summit inflatable and a thermorest compressible pillow
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: Trekology pillow on Amazon are great
data.author: Lysanne Sansoucy

data.text: First night is difficult to sleep well, more if you are not tired. Some days If Im too tired I don't put matress and sleep well (if ins not humid at all)
data.author: Oriol Martinez

data.text: My air mattress is quite comfortable, I inflate it all the way. REI Q-core.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: I use my clothing stuff sack as a pillow, just remove some clothes to make it softer, add more to make it firmer. Hopefully this could work for you too!
data.author: Caitlin McCauley

data.text: That's what I do too
data.author: John Parks

data.text: Camping hammock, use a sweater as a pillow ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Gene Pelletier

data.text: I am not sure if this is your case. If you have a mat with a built in pillow, but only one port for inflating both, get a separate matt and pillow. As already said, don't overinflate, let some of the air out. The self inflating matts are not great for comfort, and relatively heavy. Get an inflatable mat. Look for a mat with a pump sack so that you do not need to use your lungs to blow things up. Or get a mini pump like the Flextailgear Tiny X pump.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I gave up on inflatable pillows and went to compressible travel pillows
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: Are you around trees? Cus you could ditch your plans and just bring a hammok üôÉ user preference i suppose
data.author: Karl Menace

data.text: Camping 'sling' hammock. Probably no pillow needed.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: I‚Äôm a sidesleeper. I bought the thickest and warmest sleepingpad I could find that was somewhat small packedüôäüôà I‚Äôm saving for a therm-a-rest compressible pillow‚Ä¶ my inflatable sea to summit is not it for meü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: Anne Bryn

data.text:
We use lightweight cots and Camp Pillows from MEC (https://www.mec.ca/en/product/5050-907/camp-pillow?colour=Pine+Landscape+Print)
MEC Camp Pillow | MEC
mec.ca
data.author: Al Lens

data.text: Hotel room
data.author: Ian Weatherill

data.text: Exped synmat, do not fully inflate! For us the best and they have super service. Compressable small pillow or fleece jacket.
data.author: Belinda Wardenaar

data.text: We use mats that are at least 50mm high when blown up these are very comfy and used them for 132nights in tents last year over a 6 month period in Australia
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: Ride till you drop
data.author: Nicholas Heller

data.text: Selft inflatibles never sleep good same with the pillows and dont inflate the pillows fully
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Carry super glue to patch leaks!
data.author: Tom Possert

data.text: I‚Äôve used the Sea to Summit Aeros Ultralight Pillow for years and highly recommend it. So comfortable!
data.author: Jay Jermyn Johnson

data.text: Consider a hammock with integrated mosquito net?
data.author: Heinrich Benz

data.text: I bought a regular inflatable bed, thick enough for a me as a side sleeper. It is just over a kg cost about ‚Ç¨25. It has lasted me at least 20 nights, no holes yet,
data.author: Linda Tisue

data.text: Stuff sack as pillow with something in it. No need for an extra bit of kit to carry. Blow up or inflatable mattress. Microfiber towel over stuff sack for cool softness... It will dry under you in warm weather.
data.author: John Mellor

data.text: Instead of buying an inflatable pillow simply extract the silver bag from a box of wine and inflate to the right pressure. You can even have wine for breakfast! Voila! How's that for a solution to the cost of living crisis? üôÇüëç
data.author: Simon Bebe

data.text: The light waight cotts have really came a long way.. in 52 years old, an starting to think the cott is the way to go.. I come to the conclusion , even the best sleep maps suck.. an I'm just use too it.. some a lil betters then others.. but still just a mat on the ground.. there newer an constant up grades being thrown around . So, very expensive.. but there coming around.
data.author: Buck Murphy

data.text: I bought a 3 cm thick decathlon self-inflating mattress that I find very comfortable, with a R-Value of 3.8 (high) but a rather heavy weight of 1.3kg, but on a bike you can carry heavier! I can then add a folding floor mat for added comfort. We can try in the store
data.author: Soso Lxne

data.text: I gave up on sleeping on the ground. a hammock is much more comfortable. the Hennessey allows side sleeping in great comfort.
data.author: Miko Sloper

data.text: Hammock
data.author: S√∏ren Davidsen

data.text: A piece of shit. pillow that you fill with your clothes the top, it's been 10 years that we've been doing this
data.author: Valerie Vava

data.text: Last year I took a matt, a therma rest self inflating, given to me by good friend. It was a waist of time and weight. Roll over, off the pad you are. It made little difference in comfort when I was on it. Personally, I won't bother to carry a matt again. I've always slept fine without one. Just find a nice spot to pitch the tent. I'm 65, have done many tours, never felt the need for a matt. And I won't ever bring one again.. Good luck to you whatever you decide, enjoy your ride.
data.author: Tom Micele
